text: County School Board to order. For our moment of silence, we'd like to have a special remembrance of one of our teachers who passed recently.  Powerful ideas sometimes are described as throwing a rock in a river and watching it generate huge ripples that keep getting larger until they encompass a large area. This analogy can fit people as well as ideas. And so it was with Pete Fittner. To give you a sense of the length of his service, he was hired by Joe Vining to teach at Brownsville right out of ed school. In those days, Brownsville had 180 students.  Pete also supported math students at Aetna Hurt and Woodbrook, and taught at Burleigh, where he received our community's highest award for teaching, the Golden Apple.  His principal, Cassandra Blount, called him a trifecta as a teacher. She described his three superpowers as always building confidence in his students, treating students in a way that makes them want to reach their highest expectations, and he was so skilled in his methods that he could easily adapt to any student's need. He was known at Burleigh as King of the Dungeon, referring to the sixth grade's location on the basement level floor of the school.  When you help kids begin to find their place in the world, Pete once said, you begin to find yourself too. Once you embrace who you are, the more you can give to help the students. If you are doing it right, the kids help you through the day. They help you as much as you help them. I want my students to fight for themselves and what they believe in was one of Pete's favorite thoughts. I tell them fight for you and fight for what you want.  No matter what happens, you have to keep moving forward. You have to keep fighting. Pete's wife, Nancy, who teaches at Brownsville, said he kept doing that right up until this week. And Pete passed yesterday afternoon. Our condolences and our gratitude go out to the Fittner family. And the next time we see a ripple in that water, we will think of Pete and all the lives that he lifted up. We will now have a moment of silence.  This meeting being conducted electronically, we have to read this into our minutes for each meeting. The minutes of this meeting should reflect that this meeting is being held electronically, pursuant to Virginia state law and Albemarle County ordinance, because the COVID-19 pandemic  makes it impracticable and unsafe to assemble a quorum physically in a single location. The meeting is being communicated to the public electronically through Zoom and streamed live on the Albemarle County Public Schools website. And public comment may be offered through the Zoom waiting room feature in accordance with the school board's protocol or by written submission. And now to introduce our board members, Dr. Kate Acuff,

text: Thank you. All right, our COVID update, Dr. McLaughlin and Ms. Gomez.
speaker: grahampaige

text: All right, good evening board members. I'm Pat McLaughlin, the chief of strategic planning for the school division. And I'm here tonight with Eileen Gomez to provide our COVID update. So let's go ahead and get started. As you know, we have realigned the format of our update with the most recent guidance provided to us by the Virginia Department of Health and the Virginia Department of Education.  And as all public schools in Virginia are now required to open five days a week for in-person instruction, the guidance is no longer geared toward the conditions under which schools should open for students, but the newly updated guidance instead provides five steps for school divisions to consider as operational decisions, whoops, as operational decisions are made for and during the 21-22 school year. So the first of these is to evaluate the current level of community disease transmission.  The level of community transmission is determined using two measures. The first is the total number of new cases per 100,000 people in the past seven days. The most recent data we have is from Tuesday, August 24, and at that time our current seven day total per 100,000 people was about 108, putting us in the high transmission category.  The second measure is the percent of NAAT tests that are positive during the past seven days. Our latest percent positivity is 4.6%, which puts us in the low transmission category. When the two indicators are at different levels, the VDH recommends using the indicator with the higher value as your community transmission level. So our current community transmission level is at the high level. The second step is to understand the level of community vaccination.  And our vaccination rates, I'm happy to say again, continue to be a bright spot for us. In Albemarle County, we have 81.8% of 12 to 15 year olds and 85.5% of 16 to 17 year olds receiving at least one dose of the COVID-19 vaccine. Those numbers are up from 78.2 and from 83.2 respectively since we last updated the board.  Our fully vaccinated numbers for our 12 to 15 year olds are 71.8% up from 68.5. And for our 16 and 17 year olds, they are at 77.6 up from 75.8. And so the third step is to consider the level of impact that the virus is having within our schools.  You'll recall that last week, last board meeting, we couldn't report on this because we didn't have students in school, but now that they're back, we can again use this metric in our operational strategy. And as expected, we have had sporadic cases in our schools as students return this week, but to date have no evidence of transmission within our schools. So we consider that indicator to be low. Student and staff absenteeism is not being impacted to a large degree by the pandemic. And each of these indicators, along with our overall indicator,  are at the low level. And I'd like to remind the board that our COVID dashboard is live and up to date. You can access it from the homepage of the Albemarle County Schools site. And if you go to the dashboard, you'll see that this week we have had 12 total positive cases in our schools. Eight of those were student cases and four of those were staff cases. And that's resulted in a total current quarantine of 21 students and one staff member.  The final two steps that we use to determine, yes. Do you know if the members of the staff that had it were vaccinated? That I do not know. I would defer to Eileen. I'm not sure we know that or not. Eileen, do you have any information on that?
speaker: patrickmclaughlin

text: I do know that one of them was not vaccinated.
speaker: eileengomez

text: And are the students that have been hit, are they in the range where they can be vaccinated or are they younger than that?
speaker: davidoberg

text: There's been some of both.
speaker: eileengomez

text: So moving on the final two steps of final two pieces that we need to do is understand the community and and school needs and determine our best mitigation strategies that we have and as you recall, we looked at the nine key prevention strategies that were provided by  The CDC and the Virginia Department of Health, and we feel like our current mitigation plan is an effective one in preventing the spread within our schools again we were expecting some sporadic cases, but we have not seen any cases of transmission within our schools.  to date since we opened up. And finally tonight, I'd like to provide you with some updated information about our staff vaccination program for the board's resolution, beginning September 15 always CPS employees are going to be required to be vaccinated or show proof of a weekly negative coven test.  Employees will attest to their vaccination status through a survey and will be asked to show proof of vaccination if contact tracing is needed. That survey is set to launch no later than Monday, August 30. We may have it out as soon as tomorrow. And once it does launch for our employees, they're going to have one week to complete it and send that information into us.  As you know, we want to keep everything confidential, so vaccination status will not be shared unless that knowledge is necessary for contact tracing. And as vaccine status changes, employees will update us with that information. In terms of the testing of employees who choose not to get vaccinated, we are currently in the procurement process for a COVID testing provider and hope to have more information on that in the very near future.  And so I thank you for your time tonight. And Eileen and I and other staff members would be happy to take any questions or comments you might have about where things stand with our COVID update.

The Being a Reader program provides opportunities to build relationships in a deliberate way. In the beginning of the school year, students learn how to gather and use cooperative structures in which they are responsible to one another. Students work with partners during shared reading lessons. During this time, students participate in an activity called Turn to Your Partner. They are given a question to ponder and then a chance to talk about what they're thinking with their peer.  As the year progresses, students regularly discuss and solve problems related to their work together. As their relationships evolve, students feel connected to their peers. Therefore, they learn to take risks to grow academically and socially. The guide, excuse me, social and academic learning flourish when they are integrated and the Being a Reader program does this in a systematic way. And being that this is my third year teaching,  I'm being a reader and afraid I observed my students feel successful confident learners by using this program.
